Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that cooperation with others depends on shared understanding of social conventions, including turn-taking language, which vary according to the degree of formality
Elaboration: Recognising and using collaborative language in group and pair work; for example, initiating a topic, changing a topic through negotiation, affirming other speakers and building on their comments, asking relevant questions, providing useful feedback, prompting, and checking individual and group understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how the language of evaluation and emotion can be varied to be more or less forceful
Elaboration: Recognising how choice of adverbs, nouns and verbs present different evaluations of characters in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how the language of evaluation and emotion can be varied to be more or less forceful
Elaboration: Exploring examples of language that demonstrate a range of emotions and positions, and building a vocabulary to express judgements about characters or events, for example ‘The wizard was cunning, expert, inventive’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how different types of texts across the curriculum have different language features and structures depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the stages of a basic argument such as introduction, argument 1, argument 2 and conclusion

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how different types of texts across the curriculum have different language features and structures depending on purposes
Elaboration: Describing the typical text structure and language features of factual recounts, autobiographies, information reports, narratives, personal responses to literary texts (with reasons), sequential explanations, verse poetry and simple arguments, and describing their purposes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that paragraphs are a key organisational feature of the stages of written texts, grouping related information together
Elaboration: Recognising that longer informative texts are organised into paragraphs, which begin with a topic sentence that predicts how the paragraph will develop and is then elaborated on in various ways

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that paragraphs are a key organisational feature of the stages of written texts, grouping related information together
Elaboration: Recognising that paragraphs in narrative texts vary in length and do not always follow a predictable structure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that paragraphs are a key organisational feature of the stages of written texts, grouping related information together
Elaboration: Examining models of well-constructed paragraphs and identifying their features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose of layout features in print and digital texts and the words used for navigation
Elaboration: Examining the words used as hyperlinks

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose of layout features in print and digital texts and the words used for navigation
Elaboration: Discussing words used as headings and subheadings in digital and print information texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose of layout features in print and digital texts and the words used for navigation
Elaboration: Discussing words used for chapter headings in narratives

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a clause is a unit of grammar usually containing a subject and a verb that need to agree
Elaboration: Identifying clauses in texts by locating verbs and the key words that link to the verbs, for example ‘While the cat slept, the mouse scurried across the path.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a clause is a unit of grammar usually containing a subject and a verb that need to agree
Elaboration: Identifying that a singular subject has a singular verb, and a plural subject has a plural verb, for example ‘The girl plays cricket.’ and ‘The girls play cricket.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Exploring ‘doing’ and ‘saying’ verbs in narrative texts to understand how they give information about what characters do and say

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Exploring the use of ‘sensing’ verbs and how they allow readers to understand what characters think and feel, for example ‘He remembered his first day at school.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Exploring the use of ‘relating’ verbs in constructing definitions and descriptions; for example, identifying the relating verb ‘is’ or ‘are’, ‘has’ or ‘have’ in descriptions of animals

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Identifying different types of verbs and the way that they control meaning in a clause

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that verbs are anchored in time through tense
Elaboration: Learning how time is represented through the tense of a verb (for example, ‘She arrived.’ or ‘She is arriving.’) and adverbials of time (for example, ‘She arrived yesterday.’ or ‘She is arriving in the morning.’)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that verbs are anchored in time through tense
Elaboration: Learning that tenses for some verbs are formed by changing the word, for example ‘She catches the ball.’ or ‘She caught the ball.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how modal verbs indicate obligation, probability and possibility
Elaboration: Exploring how modal verbs (for example, ‘must’, ‘might’ and ‘could’) indicate degrees of probability or obligation

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify how images and sound extend the meaning of a text
Elaboration: Recognising how the relationship between characters can be depicted in images through the positioning of the characters; for example, facing each other or facing away from each other, the distance between them, the relative size, one character looking up (or down) at the other (power relationships), facial expressions and body gestures

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify how images and sound extend the meaning of a text
Elaboration: Recognising how images construct a relationship with the viewer through a direct gaze into the viewer’s eyes, inviting involvement, and how close-ups are more engaging than distanced images, which can suggest alienation or loneliness

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and using technical words to describe length, for example metric units of length such as ‘millimetre’ and ‘centimetre’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and using words to describe features of narratives, for example ‘character’, ‘plot’ and ‘setting’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Identifying words that have different meanings in different contexts, for example ‘warm temperature’ and ‘warm character’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Extending vocabulary by adding prefixes and suffixes to base words, for example ‘different’, ‘differently’ and ‘difference’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that apostrophes signal missing letters in contractions, and how apostrophes are used to show singular and plural possession in regular and irregular nouns
Elaboration: Using apostrophes to create contractions; for example, ‘do not’ becomes ‘don’t’, ‘will not’ becomes ‘won’t’ and ‘of the clock’ becomes ‘o’clock’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that apostrophes signal missing letters in contractions, and how apostrophes are used to show singular and plural possession in regular and irregular nouns
Elaboration: Using apostrophes to show singular possession, for example ‘my friend’s book’ and ‘the princess’s shoe’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that apostrophes signal missing letters in contractions, and how apostrophes are used to show singular and plural possession in regular and irregular nouns
Elaboration: Using apostrophes to show plural possession, for example ‘the bees’ hive’ and ‘the princesses’ shoes’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that apostrophes signal missing letters in contractions, and how apostrophes are used to show singular and plural possession in regular and irregular nouns
Elaboration: Using apostrophes to show plural possessions in irregular nouns, for example ‘the children’s shoes’ and ‘the mice’s cheese’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, settings and events in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Exploring the ways in which a wide range of authors tell the same story, identifying variations in the storyline

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, settings and events in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing characters and their relationship with Country/Place and families in literature by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, settings and events in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing similarities and differences in the way that an archetype, such as a wolf, is portrayed in different versions of children’s stories by a wide range of world authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, settings and events in different contexts in literary texts by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander authors and illustrators and a wide range of Australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Exploring the ways that Australian settings are portrayed in stories

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss connections between personal experiences and character experiences in a range of literary texts and give reasons for personal preferences
Elaboration: Discussing relevant prior knowledge and past experiences to make meaningful connections to the people, places, events, issues and ideas in texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss connections between personal experiences and character experiences in a range of literary texts and give reasons for personal preferences
Elaboration: Selecting and discussing favourite texts and explaining reasons for assigning greater or lesser merit to particular texts or types of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how an author uses language and illustrations to build plots and portray characters and settings in literary texts, and explore how mood is created through settings and events
Elaboration: Identifying and discussing how the use of descriptive language creates setting, influences atmosphere and draws readers into events that follow, for example ‘The castle loomed dark and forbidding.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how an author uses language and illustrations to build plots and portray characters and settings in literary texts, and explore how mood is created through settings and events
Elaboration: Discussing the language used to describe the traits of characters in stories, their actions and motivations, for example ‘Dev was so lonely; he desperately wanted a pet, so he hatched a plan to get what he wanted.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and discuss some literary devices, including rhythm and onomatopoeia in poetry and prose, and discuss the ways that they shape the reader’s reaction
Elaboration: Discussing the effects of imagery in texts, for example the use of imagery related to nature in haiku poems

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify and discuss some literary devices, including rhythm and onomatopoeia in poetry and prose, and discuss the ways that they shape the reader’s reaction
Elaboration: Generating questions to discuss effects, for example ‘Why does the poet use onomatopoeia in this line of the poem?’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts, using or adapting language features, characters, settings, plot structures and ideas from literary texts they have encountered
Elaboration: Drawing on literary texts read, viewed and listened to for inspiration and ideas to create texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts, using or adapting language features, characters, settings, plot structures and ideas from literary texts they have encountered
Elaboration: Adapting texts read, viewed and listened to by changing the setting or revising an ending

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create texts, using or adapting language features, characters, settings, plot structures and ideas from literary texts they have encountered
Elaboration: Discussing characters encountered in literary texts and sharing ideas about how those characters may be a model for students’ own writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions to share text- or topic-based information and ideas
Elaboration: Building on and connecting ideas and opinions expressed by others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions to share text- or topic-based information and ideas
Elaboration: Listening actively, including listening for specific information, recognising the value of others’ contributions and responding through comments, recounts and summaries of information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions to share text- or topic-based information and ideas
Elaboration: Learning the specific speaking or listening skills of different group roles, for example group leader, note taker and reporter

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions to share text- or topic-based information and ideas
Elaboration: Using language appropriately in different situations; for example, explaining a procedure to a group or engaging in a game with friends

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Deliver spoken texts to an audience using features of voice
Elaboration: Adjusting tone and pace to purpose and audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of phoneme–grapheme correspondences, syllables, and blending and segmenting to fluently read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter patterns
Elaboration: Reading and writing more complex words with consonant digraphs and consonant blends, for example ‘shrinking’, ‘against’ and ‘rocket’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of phoneme–grapheme correspondences, syllables, and blending and segmenting to fluently read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter patterns
Elaboration: Reading and writing consonant digraphs representing different sounds, for example ‘machine’, ‘change’ and ‘school’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of common base words, prefixes, suffixes and generalisations for adding a suffix to a base word to read and comprehend new multimorphemic words
Elaboration: Understanding how to use knowledge of prefixes to change the meaning of a base word, for example ‘undone’, ‘remove’ and ‘misunderstand’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of common base words, prefixes, suffixes and generalisations for adding a suffix to a base word to read and comprehend new multimorphemic words
Elaboration: Using generalisations for adding a suffix to a base word to form a plural or past tense; for example, to make a word plural when it ends in ‘ss’, ‘sh’, ‘ch’ or ‘z’, add ‘es’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme–grapheme relationships and less common letter patterns to spell words
Elaboration: Using phonic knowledge to explore less common letter patterns after short vowels, for example words that end in ‘dge’, such as ‘badge’, ‘edge’ and ‘fridge’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme–grapheme relationships and less common letter patterns to spell words
Elaboration: Using phonic knowledge and knowledge of letter patterns to spell words with 3-letter blends, for example ‘str-ip’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and know how to write most high-frequency words, including some homophones
Elaboration: Using context and syntactic knowledge to spell homophones, for example ‘break’ and ‘brake’ or ‘ate’ and ‘eight’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read different types of texts using phonic, semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently for meaning, re-reading and self-correcting when required
Elaboration: Using phonic knowledge, word knowledge, vocabulary and grammatical knowledge to read unknown words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read different types of texts using phonic, semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently for meaning, re-reading and self-correcting when required
Elaboration: Reading a wider range of texts from different learning areas, including chapter books and informative texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how texts with similar purposes can be created for different audiences
Elaboration: Discussing the ways in which a safety campaign varies depending on its audience; for example, comparing how a road safety campaign for adults driving a car is different to a road safety campaign for children crossing the road

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how texts with similar purposes can be created for different audiences
Elaboration: Discussing how the instructions for assembling and using toys vary according to the age of the intended user

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose and audience of different types of texts through the use of language features and/or images in the texts
Elaboration: Identifying words, phrases and images intended to persuade listeners, viewers or readers

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose and audience of different types of texts through the use of language features and/or images in the texts
Elaboration: Identifying features of advertisements that target children

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose and audience of different types of texts through the use of language features and/or images in the texts
Elaboration: Identifying the purpose of a narrative text; for example, identifying the purpose of a fable

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Making predictions about a text, drawing on knowledge of the topic, subject-specific vocabulary and experience of texts on the same topic

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Identifying important ideas, events or details in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Learning new content from reading and listening, and asking questions to expand understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Comparing and contrasting how different texts present similar ideas or information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Drawing inferences, using evidence from the text and prior knowledge and experience; for example, making predictions about a character's likely actions or about the content of tabbed pages on a website

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies, such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning, to analyse texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features to build literal and inferred meanings
Elaboration: Determining the relevance of a text for a particular task

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Gathering information and ideas about a topic in preparation for writing, which may include information and ideas from online and digital sources

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Researching a topic to prepare an oral or multimodal presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Planning the sequence of ideas and information using techniques such as storyboards or a simple flow chart

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Explaining ideas to a peer when planning a presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Selecting an appropriate text structure for a writing purpose, and sequencing content for clarity and to have an impact on an audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using appropriate simple and compound sentences to express and combine ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using vocabulary, including topic-specific vocabulary, relevant to the type of text and purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create narrative, informative and persuasive texts, written and spoken, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, using topic-specific and precise vocabulary and multimodal elements as appropriate
Elaboration: Using digital tools to plan, sequence, compose and edit texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit texts for meaning, appropriate structure, grammatical choices and punctuation
Elaboration: Using print and online dictionaries and spellcheck to edit spelling, realising that spellcheck accuracy depends on understanding the word function, for example ‘there’ or ‘their’ and ‘rain’ or ‘reign’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Re-read and edit texts for meaning, appropriate structure, grammatical choices and punctuation
Elaboration: Checking for correct use of apostrophes for contractions and to indicate possession

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words using joined letters that are clearly formed and consistent in size
Elaboration: Content description does not require elaboration.
